revisions.rev:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox person | name = Sarah Lark | image = | imagesize = 150px | caption = Sarah performing on I'd Do Anything | birth_name = Sarah Lark | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1983|1|28|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Roath]], [[Cardiff]], [[Wales]] | othername = | occupation = [[Actress]], [[Singer]] | yearsactive = 1995–present | spouse = | children = | awards = | website = | notable role = }}
'''Sarah Lark''' (born 28 January 1983) is a [[Wales|Welsh]] [[singer]] and [[actress]] who rose to fame when she competed as one of the finalists in the [[BBC]] [[talent show]]-themed [[television series]] ''[[I'd Do Anything (BBC TV series)|I'd Do Anything]]'' in 2008.<ref name="bbc-sarah">{{cite news | title = Nancy Contestants - Sarah | publisher = [[bbc.co.uk]] | date =6 February 2008 | url =http://www.bbc.co.uk/oliver/contestants/nancy/sarah.shtml | accessdate =2008-05-09 }}</ref>
==Background== Lark was born in [[Roath]], [[Cardiff]] to Bev and Billy Lark, and began performing at an early age. When she was twelve years old she played the lead role in the Starstruck Theatre production of [[Musical theatre|musical]], ''[[Annie (musical)|Annie]]'' at St Peter's Church Hall in Roath alongside [[Charlotte Church]], who took the role of Molly.<ref name="wales080326">{{cite news | title = Nancy Contestants - Sarah | publisher = [[Trinity Mirror|Media Wales Ltd]] | date =26 March 2008 | url = http://www.walesonline.co.uk/videos-and-pics/2008/03/26/songbirds-charlotte-church-and-sarah-lark-91466-20678225/ | accessdate =2008-10-10 }}</ref> She appeared in the [[television]] series ''[[The Biz (TV series)|The Biz]]'' and ''The Healer''<ref name="spotlight-lark">{{cite news | title = Sarah Lark | publisher = [[The Spotlight]] | url = http://www.spotlight.com/interactive/cv/5315-7862-4453 | accessdate = 2008-10-10}}</ref> and appeared in the original performance of the [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]] musical, ''[[Whistle Down the Wind (musical)|Whistle Down The Wind]]'' at the [[Sydmonton Festival]] held at Lloyd Webber's country house, Sydmonton Court in 1995 as part of the ensemble.<ref name="bbc-sarah"/><ref name="stage0803">{{cite news | last = Matthewman | first = Scott | title = I'd Do Anything: Meet the Nancies | publisher = [[The Stage]] | date = 25 March 2008 | url = http://blogs.thestage.co.uk/tvtoday/2008/03/id-do-anything-meet-the-nancies | accessdate = 2008-09-11}}</ref>
In 2000 Lark made her [[West End theatre|West End]] debut creating the role of "Little Girl" in [[Cameron Mackintosh]]'s production of ''[[The Witches of Eastwick (musical)|The Witches of Eastwick]]'' at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]].<ref name="aboutmaria-woe">{{cite web | title = Witches of Eastwick | publisher = About Maria - The Maria Freedman website | url = http://www.aboutmaria.com/witchesofeastwick.html | accessdate = 2008-08-21}}</ref> In 2003 she played [[John Barrowman]]'s daughter in the musical, [[Beautiful and Damned]] at the [[Yvonne Arnaud Theatre]] in [[Guildford]], [[Surrey]].<ref name="bbc-sarah"/>
After appearing as Lucy in a production of ''[[Snoopy!!! The Musical]]'' at the [[Jermyn Street Theatre]] in 2003, Lark undertook a Post-Graduate course in [[Musical theatre]] at the [[Royal Academy of Music]].<ref name="stage0803"/> Here in 2004 she played the roles of Julie in [[Victoria Wood]]'s play ''[[Talent (1978 play)|Talent]]'' and also [[Hermia]] in ''[[A Midsummer Night's Dream]]''.<ref name="spotlight-lark"/> She graduated with a [[distinction]]{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}} and then went on to reprise her role in ''Snoopy!!!'' at The New Players' Theatre in 2004. In 2005 she joined the musical ''[[Mamma Mia!]]'' at the [[Prince of Wales Theatre]], as cover for the roles of Lisa and Sophie.<ref name="bbc-sarah"/><ref name="spotlight-lark"/>
She stayed in Mamma Mia! for two years before making her first appearance at the [[Edinburgh Fringe]] Festival in 2007, performing in [[C venues|C Theatre]]'s productions of ''[[Cinderella]]'', in the title role and the annual ''Shakespeare For Breakfast'', as Juliet's nurse.<ref name="spotlight-lark"/> The latter making a successful transfer to the [[Canal Cafe Theatre]] in [[Maida Vale#Little Venice|Little Venice]], London.{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}}
==''I'd Do Anything''== Lark was a finalist on ''I'd Do Anything'' on [[BBC One]] from March to May 2008, a show which searched for a new, unknown lead to play [[Nancy (Oliver Twist)|Nancy]] in a [[West End theatre|West End]] revival of the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[musical theatre|musical]] ''[[Oliver!]]''. She was eliminated in show six on 4 May.
Immediately after the show Lark participated in the ''I'd Do Anything'' tours with fellow contestants Ashley Russell, Keisha Amponsa-Banson and [[Niamh Perry]], along with [[Michael French]] and [[Connie Fisher]], accompanied by the [[BBC Singers]] and the [[BBC Symphony Orchestra]].
After participating in a workshop production at the [[Menier Chocolate Factory]] in the [[London Borough of Southwark]], Lark performed as Collette in Conor Mitchell's ''Mathilde'' at the 2008 [[Edinburgh Comedy Festival]], directed by [[Simon Callow]].<ref name="spotlight-lark"/><ref name="edcomfest663">{{cite news | title=Mathilde by Conor Mitchell | publisher=Edinburgh Comedy Festival | url=http://www.edcomfest.com/tellMeMore.aspx?show=663 | accessdate=2008-08-24}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> In September 2008 she performed as the lead female vocalist in the show ''Hit's of the West End'' at the [[Hamilton Townhouse]], [[Hamilton, South Lanarkshire]].<ref name="advertiser21353743">{{cite news | last = Brown | first = Lesley | title= West End comes to town in autumn | publisher=Hamilton Advertiser | url=http://www.hamiltonadvertiser.co.uk/lifestyle/ml3-entertainment/2008/07/17/west-end-comes-to-town-in-autumn-51525-21353743/ | accessdate=2008-08-24}}</ref>
<ref name="playbill122868">{{cite news|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/122868.html|title=Carroll and Lark Join Company of London Oliver! Revival; Casting Now Complete|last=Shenton|first=Mark|date=30 October 2008|publisher=[[Playbill]]|accessdate=2008-10-31}}</ref> On 14 October she appeared in a one-off charity performance of the musical comedy ''[[Betwixt!]]'' at the [[Ambassadors Theatre]] in [[Covent Garden]], London.<ref name="spotlight-lark"/><ref name="ck">{{cite web | title= Actresses | publisher=Cole Kitchenn | url= http://www.colekitchenn.com/pm-actresses.htm | accessdate=2008-10-05}}</ref> On 9 November 2008 she performed a solo cabaret act ''An afternoon with Sarah Lark'', at [[Lauderdale House]] in [[Waterlow Park]], [[Highgate]] in north London.<ref name="stage34198">{{cite web|url=http://www.thestage.co.uk/listings/production.php/34198/cabaret-in-the-house-sarah-lark|title=Cabaret in the House - Sarah Lark|date=9 November 2008|publisher=[[The Stage]]|accessdate=2008-11-11}}</ref>
In February 2009, Lark performed at the 2009 [[Theatregoers' Choice Award|Whatsonstage Theatregoers' Choice Award]] at the [[Prince of Wales Theatre]] in London.<ref name="wso784">{{cite news|url=http://awards.whatsonstage.com/index.php?pg=784|title=2009 Whatsonstage.com Theatregoers' Choice Awards Concert|publisher=[[Theatregoers' Choice Award|Whatsonstage Theatregoers' Choice Award]] |accessdate=2009-03-13}}</ref> She sang [[9 to 5 (Dolly Parton song)|9 to 5]] with fellow ''I'd do Anything'' contestant [[Samantha Barks]] and ''[[The X Factor (UK series 4)|X-Factor]]'' finalist [[Niki Evans]], then the title track from the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] musical ''[[Xanadu (musical)|Xanadu]]''.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}
In November 2009 Lark performed at an all-star concert celebrating the work of young British composer [http://www.michael-bruce.co.uk/ Michael Bruce] at the [[Apollo Theatre]].<ref>http://www.whatsonstage.com/news/theatre/london/E8831251737944/All-Star+Concerts+of+Michael+Bruce+%26+Lance+Horne.html</ref> Other performers to feature in the concert included West End Stars [[Julie Atherton]], Paul Spicer and [[Leanne Jones]], [[Your Country Needs You]] finalist Mark Evans, [[Any Dream Will Do (TV series)|Any Dream Will Do]] finalist Daniel Boys, and [[How Do You Solve A Problem Like Maria?]] finalist [[Helena Blackman]].
Since 2009 Lark has been inducted as a [http://www.welshicons.org.uk/html/sarah_lark.php Welsh Icon] on Welsh cultural site [http://www.welshicons.org.uk/ welshicons.org.uk].
Also in 2009 Lark recorded the lead role of Roberta Jones in Gareth Peter Dicks' musical '''[http://www.garethpeterdicks.co.uk Bluebird]'''. Bluebird is a passionate WW2 musical concept recording that also starred [[Ramin Karimloo]] and [[Abi Finley]].
===''Oliver!''=== Lark's first major show was in [[Cameron Mackintosh]]'s revival production of ''Oliver!'' at the [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane]], [[London]], in which she played a part in the ensemble. Although she did not perform as lead Nancy, she did [[Understudy]] the part, performing it on a few occasions during the absence of [[Jodie Prenger]] in March and September 2009. Lark departed the cast on 27 March 2010 after performing in the production for 14 months.
==Discography== *''[[The Witches of Eastwick (musical)|The Witches of Eastwick]]'' - Original cast recording, as Little Girl (2000). *''[[Oliver!]]'' - Live cast recording, as Strawberry Seller (2009). *''Bluebird [http://www.garethpeterdicks.co.uk]'' - Original concept cast recording, as Roberta (2009).
